awd_titl_txt: Climate Drivers and Ancient History in Greenland Ice
awd_abstract_narration:
Ice cores collected from the polar ice sheets contain detailed records of past environmental conditions, climate, and climate drivers. For example, the timing, size, and sometimes even the locations of large volcanic eruptions can be detected in the ice. Such eruptions often were linked in the past to periods of strong cooling and changes in precipitation patterns that disrupted food production, leading to famines, human migrations, political unrest, and conflict. One such eruption led to the 'year without a summer' in 1816, which resulted in major food shortages across the Northern Hemisphere. Similarly, ice cores contain detailed records of past industrial emissions of metals, acids, and other pollutants. For example, lead pollution is an especially sensitive indicator of past mining and smelting of lead/silver ores, and because many ancient coinage was made of silver, Arctic lead pollution can be used as a proxy or indicator past silver production and so overall economic activity. Indeed, Greenland ice cores analyzed at high depth resolution with the latest analytical instruments have yielded precisely dated (within one to two years) proxies of ancient, medieval, and modern economies. When compared to known historical events such as plagues and wars, historians, economists, and archaeologists can assess the resilience of past societies through their response to external shocks such as the arrival of plagues or a climate disruptions resulting from volcanic eruptions. 

The goal of this research is to develop accurately dated, high-resolution, ice-core records of a broad range of elements and chemical species to expand and extend recently identified, causal linkages between (1) ancient societies; (2) volcanism and hydroclimate; and (3) wars, plagues, social unrest, and economic activity. Underpinning these efforts will be the collection and analysis of a ~440 m ice core from the Tunu region on the northeastern flank of the Greenland ice sheet. An ice-penetrating radar survey extending 40-km upstream along the ice-flow line upstream of the ice-core site will support interpretation of the aerosol and water isotope records, as well as understanding of any possible impacts from changes in deposition processes upstream. The ice core will be analyzed using the continuous flow analysis system at the Desert Research Institute to develop accurately-dated records of over 30 chemical species linked to volcanism, biomass burning, sea salts, continental dust, and industrial pollution during the past 4,000 years. The ice core will be dated using volcanically-constrained annual layer counting supplemented by measurements of cosmogenic nuclides from known solar proton events. Interpretation of the ice-core records will be conducted by an interdisciplinary team including environmental and climate scientists, volcanologists, historians, and social scientists. A laboratory-based course will also be developed to train historians, economists, archaeologists, and researchers from other related fields in ice-core analysis and how ice-core records can be used to address historical research questions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report.

Well-dated, high-resolution chemical measurements in polar ice cores potentially provide a means to investigate ancient societies and their vulnerability to natural (e.g., volcanism, hydroclimate, plague) and human caused (e.g.,  wars, social unrest, industry) externalities. Here we developed detailed records of pollution, volcanism, and climate using continuous measurements of a broad range of elements and chemical species in >800 m of ice, including from two new ice cores collected from remote northeast Greenland as part of this project and from archived ice cores provided by international collaboration. Together with atmospheric modelers, ancient historians and archaeologists, epidemiologists, and other researchers, we used these and existing, similarly detailed ice core records to (1) investigate early societies through their impacts on remote polar environments from settlement, conquest, and industrial activities, and (2) assess vulnerabilities and responses of early societies to externalities such as plague and volcanically driven hydroclimate perturbations. Selected findings are summarized below. 

Intellectual merit.

Industrial emissions: In the first study of its kind, we used three detailed ice core records of Arctic lead pollution, leading edge atmospheric aerosol transport and deposition modeling, and modern epidemiological relationships to quantify possible large-scale impacts of early industrial activities on human health; specifically, atmospheric lead pollution from mining and smelting of silver/lead ores that underpinned the economy of the Roman empire more than 2000 years ago. Exposure to this air pollution enhanced childhood blood lead levels, likely resulting in population-wide IQ deficits of 2.5 to 3 points during the 180-year Pax Romana, as well as other health impacts such as infertility, heart disease, immune system depression, and behavioral problems. 

Volcanism: Well-dated polar ice core records of radiatively important volcanic sulfur fallout, together with tephra geochemical fingerprinting, tree-ring temperature records, and Earth system modeling, show that explosive volcanism has been the largest driver of short-term climate variability throughout the Holocene and that associated climate variations impacted ancient and medieval agrarian societies. Among the most prominent was massive eruption of the Okmok volcano in 43 BCE in Alaska that resulted in hemispheric-scale hydroclimate changes, very likely contributing to food shortages and social unrest throughout the Mediterranean region during this critical juncture of Western Civilization at the end of the Roman republic and dawn of the Roman empire.

Settlement: Black carbon deposition measured in a wide array of six Antarctic ice cores and atmospheric modeling showed that late 13th century introduction of fire by the first Polynesian settlers in New Zealand clearly altered Southern Hemisphere atmospheric chemistry, possibly enhancing radiative forcing and fertilization of the Southern Ocean. 

Conquest: Heavy metal records from five ice cores, together with atmospheric modeling, indicated that mining and smelting in the Andes resulted in detectable pollution in Antarctica as early as the mid-16th century. While emissions from Andean metallurgy prior to European contact did not result in statistically significant heavy metal pollution in Antarctica, significant pollution reached the continent soon after the Spanish conquest of South America in the mid-1500s and industrial-scale exploitation of Andean silver/lead ore bodies such as Pototsi. This was followed by order-of-magnitude increases in lead, bismuth, and cadmium pollution in Antarctic largely from late 19th and 20th century Bolivian tin and bismuth mining and ore processing. 

Broader impacts. 

The project contributed to the training of one Ph.D. and two Master students, three post-doctoral associates, and one early career faculty at the Desert Research Institute. One postdoc is now faculty at Tuffs, one is faculty in Switzerland, and the third is still at DRI. The research team conveyed findings to the public by maintaining an online project blog, contributing to nationally and internationally televised documentaries, and creating short videos displayed at public lecture series, as well as through substantial media coverage including by outlets such as The New York Times, NBC, and Popular Science.

Products.

The detailed measurements from the Tunu2022a, Tunu2022b, and RECAP cores have been posted at the Arctic Data Center (doi:10.18739/A22F7JT09; 10.18739/A26688M5X). Datasets also have been posted with specific publications on readily available journal websites.
